questions.text: A 34-year-old ma presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation, the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The vertical and downward descent of the spleen is prevented by the phrenicocolic ligament. The phrenicocolic ligament is not attached to the spleen. It attaches the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination,there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which is the nerve most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The given clinical vignette in a patient with difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, with associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm, is suggestive of injury to the musculocutaneous nerve.

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection is the lingual nerve. It loops around the submandibular duct and hence is susceptible to injury during submandibular gland resection.

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The given clinical vignette in a patient with paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve.

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Thrombosis of the superior cerebellar artery causes cerebellar lesion which presents with ataxia and incoordination.

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sternothyroid and sternohyoid prevent the upward extension of the thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The lumbricals and interossei muscles are affected.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with the loss of pain and temperature. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is also lost. The lesion is most likely located at?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The above clinical scenario Is suggestive of lateral pontine syndrome which occurs due to a lesion located at lateral pons.

questions.text: A patient presents with drooping of angle of mouth and inability to blow. Which of the following nerve is involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

7

A facial nerve, called the 7th cranial nerve, travels through a narrow, bony canal in the skull. The nerve controls sensation and helps move tiny muscles in the face. If the nerve is damaged and stops functioning it can cause the face to droop. It can also affect tear ducts and taste sensations from the tongue.

questions.text: A patient with history of pain in both legs while taking long walk, He has developed toe gangrene and he admits to have Erectile dysfunction. Which of the following artery is involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Aorto iliac  junction 

 Aortoiliac occlusive disease is the blockage of the aorta, the main blood vessel in your body, or the iliac arteries. The iliac arteries are the branches that your aorta divides into around the level of the belly button to provide blood to your legs and the organs in your pelvis.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei is not a part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The trochlear nerve nucleus is a part of the general somatic efferent (GSE) column, not the special visceral afferent column.

questions.text: While performing an endoscopy, a constriction is felt at the oesophageal junction, 25 cm from the upper incisors. Which of the following structures is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Arch of aorta

The constriction is felt due to the arch of aorta and left bronchus crossing the esophagus at 25 cm from the upper incisor teeth.

questions.text: During surgery for patent ductus arteriosus, which anatomical structure is most susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is most susceptible to injury during surgery for patent ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: During surgical intervention on the great saphenous vein situated 2.5 cm anterior to the medial malleolus, which structure should be protected from damage during the application of ligatures around the vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Saphenous nerve

During surgery on the great saphenous vein located 2.5 cm anterior to the medial malleolus, care must be taken to protect the nearby saphenous nerve from damage during ligature placement around the vein.

questions.text: A patient presents with an inability to shrug his shoulders after a fall from the stairs. On examination, an injury to the posterior triangle of his neck is noted. Which of the following structures is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Spinal accessory nerve

In the given scenario, the patient is unable to shrug his shoulders due to an injury to the spinal accessory nerve, which is present in the posterior triangle of the neck and supplies the trapezius muscle.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Saphenous nerve

The given clinical scenario in a patient with sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve. Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following varicose vein surgery.

questions.text: A cricket player was rushed to the emergency department, unconscious after being hit in the head with the ball. NCCT head revealed an extradural hematoma at the pterion. Which of the following vessels is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Middle meningeal artery

An extradural hematoma at the pterion is a result of an injury of the anterior division of the middle meningeal artery.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with weakness of shoulder movements. Investigations revealed quadrangular space syndrome. Which of the following nerve is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Axillary nerve

The axillary nerve is likely to be affected as it is one of the contents of the quadrangular space.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presented with sudden onset of loss of pain and temperature on the right side of his face and left side of his body. He also has dysphagia and dysarthria. Thrombosis of which vessel is likely to cause the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

The given clinical features are suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome, which is seen in thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. The lateral part of the medulla is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery, a branch of the vertebral artery.

questions.text: A primigravida woman gives birth to a baby with the following defect. Identify the anomaly.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Open neural tube defect

The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing anencephaly and a contiguous bony defect of the spine, is suggestive of craniorachischisis which is an open neural tube defect that occurs due to failure of complete closure of the neural tube.
